Authors:
Enrique Ibarra-Laclette, Carlos Ariel Venancio-Rodríguez,
Antonio Acini Vásquez-Aguilar, Alexandro Alonso-Sánchez, Claudia Anahí
Pérez-Torres, Emanuel Villafán, Santiago Ramírez-Barahona, Sonia
Galicia, Victoria Sosa, Eria A. Rebollar, Carlos Lara, Antonio
González-Rodríguez, Francisco Díaz-Fleischer, Juan Francisco
Ornelas
Title:
Transcriptional responses of Psittacanthus schiedeanus
(Schltdl. & Cham.) G. Don germinated seeds reveals novel findings of
haustorium formation and its establishment into the host.
Abstract:
The mistletoe Psittacanthus schiedeanus is a hemiparasitic
shrub to Mesoamerican cloud forests. This species of mistletoe has one
of the widest host ranges of the genus, infecting native and non-native
species trees of commercial interest and is a keystone species in
interaction networks between plants, mutualist pollinators, and seed
dispersers. De novo transcriptome assembly and bioinformatics analyses
were performed on inoculated seeds at various stages of development
(from seed inoculation to haustoria formation) in order to describe
changes in the de novo assembled transcriptome, gene expression profiles
of experimentally inoculated seeds across time and. to underline the
processes of attachment and haustorial formation. Of 140,467 uniGenes
that could be annotated, 2000 were differentially expressed
uniGenes.
